resources.string: There was an error saving the information
"This screen allows the user to register new species or to add pictures to an existing one."

"This screen shows all the species saved on the device. There are 2 views for this list which can be changed using the button on the lower right side of the screen: The first view shows an expandable list with 3 levels. The first level shows the family, the second level shows the genus, the third level shows the species.
The second view shows a list of all the species with its scientific name and family. By default, they are ordered by family. Pressing the button on the lower left side of the screen toggles its label between 'Family' and 'Scientific name'. This also toggles the ordering of the list accordingly. The next button toggles between ascending and descending order. This view shows user entered species in a different color. A long tap allows the user to delete it.
In both views, tapping a species will show its details."
"This screen allows the user to write and save notes."
"This screen shows information about the Cajas National Park, the credits and information about the app. It also allows the user to send comments or suggestions and bug reports."
"This screen allows the user to search species among the ones saved on the device."

"This screen show the equivalence between inches and centimeters. It also has a converter between these two units: you can type a value in cm (left) or inches (right) then press the orange button to convert to the other unit. The conversion is made with the last value entered. To the right side of the screen is a small ruler with cm values to the left and in blue, and inches values to the right in black. The ruler's accuracy depends on your device, but the error should be minimum. The button on the lower part of the screen shows a basic compass and your current coordinates and altitude."
"This screen shows the map. In it you can start the recording of a route and visualize the species in the device. The 'Type' button allow you to change the type of map."

"This screen shows the list of saved routes. Tapping on one shows its details. A long tap on a route allows the usser to delete it. In the detail view of the route, pictures can be deleted by long tapping them."
"This screens allows the user to search species directly on Trópicos ® server. It shows a maximum of 10 results. Tapping an item on the list shows its details."

"

The Cajas massif is located 30 km west of the city of Cuenca, Azuay province in southern Ecuador. It is dominated by herbaceous páramo with scattered patches of forest.

Pleistocene glaciers carved the landscape resulting in a unique area of irregular topography with more than 235 lakes and lagoons and unparalleled scenic beauty. The climate is cold and humid; there is however, considerable daily weather variation that can change rapidly from calm to strong winds, from cloudy to intense sun, from dry to fog or drizzle, and from hard rain to hail. The minimum daily temperature is –2°C and the maximum is 18°C. The annual mean precipitation is 1200 mm. It has two access roads: the main Cuenca-Molleturo-Naranjal road, and the unpaved Cuenca-Soldados. The Área de Recreación Cajas was created in 1977 and upgraded to Cajas National Park in 1996. It comprises 28,544 hectares, between 3150 and 4450 m asl.


Read more: Study area: Cajas National Park

"

"

Páramo is a unique mountain ecosystem dominated by bunch-grasses. It is found above the tree line and up to the permanent snow line (3000-5000 m/9000-15000 ft elev.) from Venezuela to northern Peru and on mountains in Panama and Costa Rica. The word páramo i associated to treeless inhospitable plains. However, páramos have high biological diversity and endemism, and constitute a unique biota.

Plants have adapted to the cold conditions, extreme solar irradiation, low atmospheric pressure, dramatic daily fluctuations in temperature, and seasonal rains. Many plants grow very close to the ground, forming rosettes and cushion-plants, or have reduced hard leaves or are covered with a dense layer of white or silvery hairs.

Páramos along with the Andean forests, function as a buffer in the hydrological cycle, which slowly releases the fallen rain water to rivers and lakes. The water captured in the páramos benefits millions of people that use it for consumption and irrigation.

The effect of the increase in temperatures due to climate change is already observed in peaks on the higher tropical mountains with a marked glacier retreat. Changes in the páramos hydrological cycle can bring catastrophic consequences and immense economic implications for the Andean countries that depend on this ecosystem for provision of water for human consumption, for operation of hydro-electrical plants, irrigation systems.


Read more: Páramo flora project

"

"

Flóramo is a field guide to identify 100 species of wild plants found in the páramo, a vegetation type at the top of the Andes Mountains of tropical South America. It contains field images, species descriptions, and an identification key using life forms, flower colors or scientific names. A map with location of species, routes for personalized records. Additional features include searches into the Missouri Botanical Garden Tropicos® database. Flóramo currently includes plants found the in the Cajas massif of southern Ecuador, but various species are found beyond this area.

Páramo flora project is at the Missouri Botanical Garden website.

The Flora of Cajas project is a collaboration between the Missouri Botanical Garden and the Azuay Herbarium (Universidad del Azuay, Cuenca Ecuador) with Parque Nacional Cajas. We thank Etapa-Parque Nacional Cajas, Ministerio del Ambiente de Ecuador, and funding agencies for field work.

Flora of Cajas Project full site and acknowledgments is at the Missouri Botanical Garden website.


Project contact: C. Ulloa


All rights reserved.

©Missouri Botanical Garden, Science and Conservation Division
